text:
How do I dispatch on the value of a symbol?
```julia> f(x::<for symbol foo>) = println(":foo")

julia> f(x::<for symbol bar>) = println(":bar")

julia> f(:foo)
:foo```

elements.text: How do I dispatch on the value of a symbol?

julia> f(x::<for symbol foo>) = println(":foo")

julia> f(x::<for symbol bar>) = println(":bar")

julia> f(:foo)
:foo

text:
I tried, this, but can't get it to work:
<https://stackoverflow.com/a/39315024/1490584>

attachments.title: Generic dispatch with Symbols
attachments.text: I was wondering if there was a way to use Symbols for multiple dispatch, but also include a "catch-all method". i.e. something like function dispatchtest{alg<:Symbol}(T::Type{Val{alg}}) print...
attachments.fallback: Stack Overflow: Generic dispatch with Symbols

elements.text: I tried, this, but can't get it to work:

text:
```julia> f(x::Symbol) = f(Val(x))
f (generic function with 1 method)

julia> f(x::Val{:foo}) = println(":foo")
f (generic function with 2 methods)

julia> f(x::Val{:bar}) = println(":bar")
f (generic function with 3 methods)

julia> f(:bar)
:bar

julia> f(:foo)
:foo

julia> f(:baz)
ERROR: MethodError: no method matching f(::Val{:baz})```

elements.text:
julia> f(x::Symbol) = f(Val(x))
f (generic function with 1 method)

julia> f(x::Val{:foo}) = println(":foo")
f (generic function with 2 methods)

julia> f(x::Val{:bar}) = println(":bar")
f (generic function with 3 methods)

julia> f(:bar)
:bar

julia> f(:foo)
:foo

julia> f(:baz)
ERROR: MethodError: no method matching f(::Val{:baz})

text:
```julia> function dispatchtest(::Type{Val{alg}}) where alg
                  println("This is the generic dispatch. The algorithm is $alg")
              end
dispatchtest (generic function with 1 method)

julia> dispatchtest(alg::Symbol) = dispatchtest(Val{alg})
dispatchtest (generic function with 2 methods)

julia> function dispatchtest(::Type{Val{:Euler}})
                  println("This is for the Euler algorithm!")
              end
dispatchtest (generic function with 3 methods)

julia> dispatchtest(:Foo)
This is the generic dispatch. The algorithm is Foo

julia> dispatchtest(:Euler)
This is for the Euler algorithm!```

elements.text:
julia> function dispatchtest(::Type{Val{alg}}) where alg
                  println("This is the generic dispatch. The algorithm is $alg")
              end
dispatchtest (generic function with 1 method)

julia> dispatchtest(alg::Symbol) = dispatchtest(Val{alg})
dispatchtest (generic function with 2 methods)

julia> function dispatchtest(::Type{Val{:Euler}})
                  println("This is for the Euler algorithm!")
              end
dispatchtest (generic function with 3 methods)

julia> dispatchtest(:Foo)
This is the generic dispatch. The algorithm is Foo

julia> dispatchtest(:Euler)
This is for the Euler algorithm!

text: the syntax seems to be outdated in the stack overflow example

text: Perfect! Thanks you two. I see I didn't realise that I needed a generalised version of the function, like `f(x::Symbol) = f(Val(x))`
